newsitem.title: USA: LIGHT COMPANIES DOWNPLAY PHILIPS TECHNOLOGY OFFER.
newsitem.headline: LIGHT COMPANIES DOWNPLAY PHILIPS TECHNOLOGY OFFER.

text.p: Lighting companies were not turned on by an offer from Philips Lighting Co. Thursday to share its fluorescent lamp technology in a bid to stave off an environmental rule that could trim its market advantage.

Philips Lighting, a unit of Philips Electronics NV , announced an offer to show its competitors, including General Electric Co. and Osram Sylvania Inc., a unit of Siemens AG , the technology for its low-mercury fluorescent lamps.
While the companies had not actually been approached yet by Philips, they considered the offer unnecessary.
"As we have equivalent technology, we're a little bit puzzled," said Peter Bleasby, director of industry relations for Osram Sylvania.
Unlike lights with higher levels of mercury, the Philips Aldo lights do not have to be treated as hazardous waste and can be dumped in municipal landfills.
The Aldo lights have 80 percent less mercury than the industry average, according to the company.
Mercury is a major problem because when it gets into water from air emissions or leaching, it collects in fish tissue, which people eat.
It is considered most dangerous for pregnant women and children.

Philips is concerned that the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency is going to propose a new rule for fluorescent lamps which will ease disposal requirements and eliminate the advantage of producing the lower-mercury lamp.

"We think by doing this (offering the technology), no company should have an exclusion that allows mercury to enter the ecosystem," Larry Wilton, president and CEO of Philips Lighting Co., said at a press conference.
Osram Sylvania and GE said they both already are producing low-mercury lights. However, they are not shifting their whole lines to the new technology as Philips is doing.
GE has been selling a light since January that it said passed the U.S. standard for lights that do not need to be disposed of as hazardous waste.

GE's vice president of product management, George Murphy, added that the Philips offer was "a little unusual," since the company already has a cross-licensing agreement to look at other companies' technology.

The 500 million lamps that are disposed of annually have about 70 tons of mercury in them. By contrast, coal-fired power plants annually emit about 3000 tons of mercury into the air, according to the Alliance to Save Energy.
Alliance to Save Energy president David Nemtzow said the environment would be better off if Philips had focused on making more energy-efficient light bulbs that would help curb power plant emissions.
"They're saying they're environmentally friendly, but they're only telling you half the story," said Nemtzow, pointing to industry-wide efforts to block federal standards for light bulb efficiency.
